DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
9th January 2020

GEOPOLITICS

Sources note three rockets have been fired into Baghdad's Green Zone, starting a fire. U.S. aircraft is reportedly airborne after missile hits near U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, according to Sky News Arabia. (Twitter) Iraq military says two rockets fell inside Baghdad's green zone; no causalities reported. (Newswires)

US President Trump says no Americans or Iraqi lives were lost by Iran strike, and added that Iran appears to be standing down. Trump said the US is to immediately impose more sanctions on Iran as it looks at options to respond. Trump stated that Just because US has strong military equipment, does not mean the US has to use it; economic strength is the best deterrent. The President also said US allies must abandon 2015 JCPOA, but world powers can work on a new deal; allies must work together to send unified message to Iran and called on NATO to get more involved. Trump said US is ready to embrace peace, can work with Iran on battling ISIS. Trump reiterated that as long as he is President, Iran will never be allowed to have a nuclear weapon. (White House)

Iranian Armed Forces Spokesman states their response to any new U.S. move will be stronger and broader, according to Al Jazeera. (Al-Jazeera)

US Pentagon reportedly stating that Iran intentionally missed US troops at the targeted bases overnight., according to Dagres a Middle East commentator. (Newswires)

Iraqi Militia Leader states that the first Iranian response happened, and it is now time for the first Iraq response; noting this will not be lesser than the response from Iran was. (Newswires)

Western Intelligence agencies reportedly assess the Boeing (BA) jet, which crashed last night, was not bought down by a missile, but a technical malfunction as there is evidence the engine overheated, according to a Canadian security source. (Newswires) US intelligence looking into Boeing (BA) 737 crash in Tehran, according to CNN. (CNN)

Turkish Foreign Minister says that Turkish President Erdogan and Russian President Putin are calling for a ceasefire in Libya on the 12th of January at midnight. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US congressional study calls for human rights sanctions on China, Reuters reports; calls on officials to keep human rights concerns in mind in dealings with Beijing, including in trade negotiations. (Newswires)

China is reportedly picking up soybean cargoes in Brazil, the report notes it dashes hopes for large US sales immediately after the signing of the Phase One deal next week. (Newswires)

World Bank cuts 2019 global growth forecast to 2.4% (Prev. 2.6%) and cuts 2020 forecast to 2.5% (Prev. 2.7%) due to slower-than-expected recovery in trade and in investments. Cuts 2019 EM growth forecasts to 3.5% (Prev. 4.0%) and cuts 2020 forecast to 4.1% (Prev. 4.6%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was clear the UK would not extend the implementation period into 2021, noting any future partnership with the EU must not involve alignment or ECJ jurisdiction, says UK PM Spokesman. States UK would keep control of UK fishing waters and its immigration methods. (Newswires)

France's CFDT Union leader states a deal with the government on the pension reform is still far away. (Newswires)

ECB's Lagarde said the biggest threat to the economy is a downturn in trade resulting from a range of uncertainties, primarily affecting manufacturing and hampering investment. It makes sense to use all of the tools at our disposal when it comes to increasing growth, which will also result in inflation moving towards levels close to 2%. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US President Trump noted the US has achieved energy independence, and that helps to shape its response; and added that US does not need Middle East oil. (White House)

UN investigation reportedly found that Yemen Houthi's did not launch the attacks on the oil facilities in Saudi Arabia last September, according to a confidential report seen by Reuters. (Newswires)

Russia's Energy Minister Novak said OPEC+ always have the ability to meet in response to a question about a possible meeting due to the tensions in the Middle East. (Newswires)

Libya's NOC Chair announced it has raised production rates to 1.174mln BPD (Prev. 1.15mln BPD in December). (Newswires)

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 1.164M vs. Exp. -3.572M (Prev. -11.463M) US EIA Weekly Crude Production 12.9M (Prev. 12.9M)

 

US

DATA RECAP

-        US ADP National Employment* (Dec) 202k vs. Exp. 160.0k (prev. revised up to 124k from 60k). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.5% at 3253.06; NDX +0.75% at 8912.37, DJI +0.57% at 28745.47; SECTORS: IT +1.032%, communications +0.72%, telecoms +0.69%, health care +0.65%, financials +0.54%, materials +0.49%, consumer staples +0.45%, industrials +0.23%, consumer discretionary +0.15%, utilities +0.0%, energy -1.74%. * STOCK SPECIFICS: The energy sector (XLE, XES, CVX, XOM, COP) was the worst performer amid the fall in crude prices as geopolitical tensions eased. Meanwhile, Tesla (TSLA) continued its rally on the increased risk appetite. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) traded at the bottom of the Dow after a disappointing quarter, as well as expressing some headwinds from withdrawing out of tobacco. Boeing (BA) also trailed the Dow following a fatal 737-800 jet crash in Iran, shortly after take-off in what appears to be a technical fault (although the incident is reportedly being looked at by US intelligence). Conversely, United Health (UNH) topped the index, supported by a PT rise to USD 366 from USD 291, citing a strong longer-term outlook for its OptumHealth unit, as well as its core insurance unit. American Express (AXP) traded higher after the PBOC approved its license to start-up operations in China; competitor Visa (V) and other financials were also firmer. Vertex (VRTX) was a top performer after having its PT raised to USD 265 at both Oppenheimer and Citi, who are both optimistic about its Trikafta launch and the latter naming it a Top Pick. Lennar (LEN) was firmer on a strong quarterly report, supporting homebuilders in general (XHB). Liberty Global (LBTYA) took a haircut after Citi lowered its PT to USD 21 from USD 25, citing a sustained negative outlook.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLE TICKS 12+ LOWER AT 128-24+. Yields were higher across curve, with a very slight steepening bias, inspired by improving geopolitics in the Middle East, while on the data slate, ADP payrolls surprised to the upside. The US 10-year auction tailed by a chunky 1.6bps basis – the largest since August. However, analyst noted that this was likely a function of geopolitics, which saw 10-year yields drop to as low as 1.7050%, before rising back towards around 1.85% heading into the auction. The rest of the metrics fared better, with cover coming in at 2.45x, a touch above the previous and recent averages. In terms of the breakdown, dealers took down slightly more than recent averages, as did direct bidders, leaving indirects with a takedown below recent averages. SocGen thinks the 30-year sector appears slightly cheap in asset swap. The bank also notes that the current WI is trading below the last two auction stop-out rates, which could indicate relative richness, compared to those auctions. The December 30-year auction saw healthy demand, stopping through by a whopping 2.1bps, and ending the run of tails. SocGen also notes that 5s30s has steepened since the previous auction cycle, which might speak to the relative cheapness of the sector. The bank has a positive bias going into the auction.

subject: Iraq military says two rockets fell inside Baghdad's green zone; no causalities reported
Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th January 2020: Stocks hit fresh record highs as Trump avoids escalation tensions with Iran
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Iran attack US Airbase in Iraq overnight, no US casualties; Trump issues sanctions, de-escalating tensions; Congressional study calls for sanctions on China over human rights abuse; ADP beats expectations; weak 10-year auction.
  • COMING UP: Data: Aussie trade, China CPI, German Industrial Output & trade, US Jobless Claims. Speakers: BoE Governor Carney, Fed’s Clarida, Williams and Evans, ECB’s Lane, BoC’s Poloz. Supply: US 30-year auction

* IRAN: After Iran launched rockets at US bases in Iraq overnight, initially seeing a sharp risk-off move, traders digested comments from the nation, which stated that its actions were a proportional response, in self defense, which commentators said demonstrates that Iran wishes to draw a line under its retaliation, putting the onus on the US as to whether the situation escalates. An unnamed White House official reportedly said that Iran's strike was seen as a move that would let Iran retaliate without incurring a potentially devastating US counter assault; there is also a thinking that the Iranian response was designed more to play to its domestic crowd. US President Trump added to the dovish tone, announcing that Iran appears to be standing down, and chose to pursue a sanctions route, rather than military action. Haven assets saw some downside as Trump avoided escalation military tensions in the Middle East. USDJPY and US equity futures continued to rise with both assets printing fresh session highs; cash markets hit an all-time high for the S&P500, and USDJPY broke 109 to the upside. Given there is no current military response from the US, Iran will likely hold fire on any further attacks as they previously announced they would re-attack with a ‘crushing effect’ if the US were to respond. On the JCPOA, Trump called for allies to abandon the deal, noting world powers can work on a new deal. In the tail end of the session it is worth noting a Reuters witness reportedly heard two blasts and sirens in Baghdad, Iraq, although the cause is unknown. Separate reports citing police sources noted three rockets fell inside the greenzone, which is near the US embassy, and resulted in a fire in the greenzone.

* US ADP: The ADP's gauge showed 202k payrolls were added to the US economy in December, eclipsing the consensus 160k; the prior also saw a healthy upward revision, to 124k from 60k. Analysts said the data introduced some upside risks for the official employment situation report, due for release on Friday. With that said, the usual caveats were offered, noting that the ADP measure of payrolls uses lagged official NFP data as a variable; this might mean that the December gain was buoyed bu the 266k added in November; but Capital Economics notes that the latter included the impact of GM workers returning from strikes, and that means that the ADP might be overestimating the strength of payroll gains in December. "Moreover," Capital Economics writes, "the accuracy of the ADP's first estimate of monthly employment growth has never been anywhere near as good as we would have expected given the richness of the data source," but nevertheless, "this latest ADP reading supports our view that employment and GDP growth held up surprisingly well in the fourth quarter, even though some of the survey evidence weakened further."

* US-CHINA: A congressional study from the US which focused on the treatment of Uighur Muslims, led by GOP Rubio and Democrat McGovern, called for sanctions on China over human rights abuses as the report believes authorities in China may be committing crimes against humanity. The report also called on officials to keep human rights in mind when dealing with Beijing, and even in trade talks. No further comments were made from US officials following the release of the report, nor from the Chinese side, however it is worth noting the Phase One deal was kept as a separate issue from the situation in Hong Kong and human rights issues.

* WTI (G0) SETTLES USD 3.09 LOWER AT USD 59.61/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLES USD 2.83 LOWER AT USD 65.44/BBL Energy markets had an erratic 24 hours before ultimately settling significantly lower. Front-month crude futures spiked higher overnight amid the Iranian strike on the US-affiliated base in Iraq, although soon reversed the move after it became clear attack had little serious damage, with no reported US casualties. The move lower was exacerbated after President Trump formally announced the US would not take a military response and instead resort to its usual method of sanctions; Trump also confirmed there had been no US casualties. Elsewhere, the EIA weekly inventory report (bbls) showed crude stocks building 1.2mln, against expectations for a draw, whilst the products both built significantly more than expected (gasoline +9.1mln and distillates +5.3mln); although markedly bearish for an inventory report, the tape action was limited as participants were anxious ahead of Trump’s formal announcement, where there was the risk of a ramp-up in the geopolitical risk premium, although once abated, the report only supported the move lower through till settlement.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.5% at 3253.06; NDX +0.75% at 8912.37, DJI +0.57% at 28745.47; SECTORS: IT +1.032%, communications +0.72%, telecoms +0.69%, health care +0.65%, financials +0.54%, materials +0.49%, consumer staples +0.45%, industrials +0.23%, consumer discretionary +0.15%, utilities +0.0%, energy -1.74%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: The energy sector (XLE, XES, CVX, XOM, COP) was the worst performer amid the fall in crude prices as geopolitical tensions eased. Meanwhile, Tesla (TSLA) continued its rally on the increased risk appetite. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) traded at the bottom of the Dow after a disappointing quarter, as well as expressing some headwinds from withdrawing out of tobacco. Boeing (BA) also trailed the Dow following a fatal 737-800 jet crash in Iran, shortly after take-off in what appears to be a technical fault (although the incident is reportedly being looked at by US intelligence). Conversely, United Health (UNH) topped the index, supported by a PT rise to USD 366 from USD 291, citing a strong longer-term outlook for its OptumHealth unit, as well as its core insurance unit. American Express (AXP) traded higher after the PBOC approved its license to start-up operations in China; competitor Visa (V) and other financials were also firmer. Vertex (VRTX) was a top performer after having its PT raised to USD 265 at both Oppenheimer and Citi, who are both optimistic about its Trikafta launch and the latter naming it a Top Pick. Lennar (LEN) was firmer on a strong quarterly report, supporting homebuilders in general (XHB). Liberty Global (LBTYA) took a haircut after Citi lowered its PT to USD 21 from USD 25, citing a sustained negative outlook.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLE TICKS 12+ LOWER AT 128-24+. Yields were higher across curve, with a very slight steepening bias, inspired by improving geopolitics in the Middle East, while on the data slate, ADP payrolls surprised to the upside. The US 10-year auction tailed by a chunky 1.6bps basis – the largest since August. However, analyst noted that this was likely a function of geopolitics, which saw 10-year yields drop to as low as 1.7050%, before rising back towards around 1.85% heading into the auction. The rest of the metrics fared better, with cover coming in at 2.45x, a touch above the previous and recent averages. In terms of the breakdown, dealers took down slightly more than recent averages, as did direct bidders, leaving indirects with a takedown below recent averages. SocGen thinks the 30-year sector appears slightly cheap in asset swap. The bank also notes that the current WI is trading below the last two auction stop-out rates, which could indicate relative richness, compared to those auctions. The December 30-year auction saw healthy demand, stopping through by a whopping 2.1bps, and ending the run of tails. SocGen also notes that 5s30s has steepened since the previous auction cycle, which might speak to the relative cheapness of the sector. The bank has a positive bias going into the auction.

* BOE: Outgoing governor Carney told the FT that central banks would have less ammunition in the next downturn, although he does not believe that monetary policy is a spent force, citing rate cuts by the Fed and ECB in 2019, stating that we are now starting to see that stimulus flow to the global economy. Meanwhile, Carney also reiterated the somewhat fashionable line among central bankers, calling on fiscal authorities to do more to stimulate economies.

* BREXIT: EU Commission President von der Leyen stated there is not enough time for a full new partnership deal between Britain and the EU before year-end as the time frame is very tight; noting the EU wants zero tariffs, quotas and dumping. Von der Leyen said we will have to prioritise this year’s agenda, in the event the negotiating timeline is not extended, however, she would prefer to look at the whole situation prior to summer this year, as the time frame may then be reconsidered (NOTE: The deadline to extend the implementation period is the end of June). She did note talks regarding a future deal are not an all or nothing situation. Despite Von der Leyens’ issues with the time frame, UK PM Johnson is sticking to his guns and as he was clear that the UK will not extend the implementation period into 2021, adding any partnership with the EU must not include alignment or ECJ jurisdiction, plus the UK would maintain its immigration methods and fishing waters.

* GERMAN FACTORY ORDERS (NOV): Orders missed expectations in November, at -1.3% M/M; the street had expected a rise of 0.2%. The Y/Y rate worsened to -6.5% from -5.6%. The previous data, however, saw a decent upward revision (+0.6ppts), which helps ease some of the gloom, though the numbers are still far from encouraging, analysts say. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that demand was constrained 3.1% M/M fall in export orders, offsetting the 1.6% rise in demand to the domestic economy. "The weakness in foreign demand was split almost equally between falling orders to EZ and non-EZ economies. Across sectors, a sustained decline in new orders for capital goods were the main driver of weakness mid-way through Q4, offsetting stable data for intermediate and consumer goods." Pantheon suggests it is futile to build a story based on the extremely volatile monthly numbers, but the underlying trend tells its own sobering story: "Growth in new orders decelerated sharply from almost +10% Y/Y at the end of 2017 to around -6.0% at the beginning of 2019, where it has more-or-less stayed since," and adds that "the only positive story at the moment is that the surveys appear to have stabilised, now indicating that growth in new orders shouldn’t fall further, but they also point to little in the way of a rebound at the start of the year."

* FX: USD continued its climb today and extended gains through the 97.00 handle in early trade, as participants began unwinding haven bids as geopolitical tensions eased An ADP payrolls beat also added to the upside. The strength in the greenback saw EURUSD continue to back-off 1.12, finding support just above the 1.11 handle. GBP was also weaker against the buck, but also amid warnings from the EU Commission President, who stated that a full trade deal by the end of the year might not be possible. Following Trump’s remarks, where he confirmed no military response would be taken for now, CAD lost further ground as oil prices continued to sell off, dragging USDCAD back above 1.30, topping out around 1.3040. Elsewhere risk sensitive currencies (AUD,NZD) caught a bid against on an improving risk backdrop; havens were offered, with USDJPY breaking 109 to the upside, with technicians now eyeing 109.50, followed by December’s high of 109.72. XAU initially breached 1600 to the upside overnight, but given the de-escalation, the yellow metal retraced back towards 1550 handle. Real yields continued to edge upwards, also adding to the pressure for gold. EMFX took its cues from the risk tone, and was stronger, with outperformance seen in TRY (a net oil importer) catching tailwinds from the falling oil prices, while RUB also an outperformer despite the country being a net oil exporter as the reduced geopolitical tensions seemingly outweigh the costs of lower oil prices for the nation.

subject: US Sells USD 24bln of 10-year notes; Tail: 1.6bps; B/C: 2.45x

content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction anew 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday) and a 30-year re-opening (USD 16bln, Thursday). UBS says there will be a total of USD 26bln of cash flows (ex SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons; over the next four weeks, gross supply will total USD 191bln, the bank notes. 

10-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts say the 10-year sector has slight set up for the upcoming auction from a relative-value perspective, and the bank feels it looks cheap in both asset swap and on the fly versus 5s and 30s. On an outright basis, the sector appears somewhat rich compared to the last auction cycle, but still appears cheaps on 2s10s given that the curve has steepened since the last auction. SocGen observes that the current 10 trades special in repo, which indicates strong demand for the issue, while the low dealer holdings in the 7-10 year sector might also be a positive. "We expect fear of escalating geopolitical risks to put a cap on bond yields in the near term, thereby increasing demand among investors for safe assets like Treasuries," SocGen says, adding "we are positive on this auction."

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar resumes early 2020 renaissance after Iranian assault
content:
DXY

All eyes, or rather ears on US President Trump for his eagerly awaited statement on Iran from 16GMT to see if relatively sanguine tweets since the overnight missile attacks are truly indicative of his assessment, and the market perception that Iran’s riposte will not prompt a further escalation in hostilities. In the interim, Greenback recovery momentum remains intact amidst a broad rebound against its G10 currency adversaries, and even bigger reversals from post-Iraq strike lows vs safer havens. However, sentiment could easily swing again depending on what emanates from the White House shortly as the index holds just above 97.000 within a 97.239-96.796 band, and from a technical standpoint not far below near term chart resistance (97.350 almost aligning with the December 26 low at 97.344). For the record and fundamentally, a stellar ADP jobs survey ahead of Friday’s BLS report bodes well and is likely to be underpinning the Buck.

EUR/JPY

The major underperformers and biggest victims of the aforementioned Dollar revival, aside from Gold as the prime safe asset and in stark contrast to the Swiss Franc that has pared losses vs the Greenback and rallied at the expense of the Euro. Eur/Usd only just evaded a test of 1.1100 and option expiries in the vicinity (1 bn from the round number up to 1.1105), while Usd/Jpy extended its sharp turnaround beyond 100 pips with a spike to circa 108.80 after reports via Kuwait that US troops were pulling out of Baghdad that were quickly dismissed due to hacking. However, the Xau/Usd volte face was even more pronounced and headline-grabbing given the break of 1600/oz and subsequent about turn to just under 1570. 

NZD/CAD/AUD

No watershed Wednesday, but a marginally better midweek session for the Aussie, Loonie and Kiwi, at least in terms of net losses relative to their US counterpart compared to yesterday. Nzd/Usd is holding in above 0.6600, though sub-0.6650 and Usd/Cad is still respecting the pre-1.3050 peak even though crude continues to hand back latest geopolitical premiums with additional downside after an EIA inventory build contrary to consensus and last night’s API draw. Meanwhile, Aud/Usd is hovering around 0.6850, with some assistance from a significantly stronger than expected resurgence in Australian building approvals, but still looking vulnerable in cross flows as Aud/Nzd seems intent to revisit lows ahead of 1.0300.

GBP

Sterling has endured another roller-coaster ride across the board, due to order driven or indirect trade rather than anything obvious on the UK specific front, with more stops and fix positioning touted in Cable and Eur/Gbp between 1.3170-1.3080 and 0.8455-0.8515 respective parameters. However, breaking Brexit news after the imminent POTUS address could provide some independent impetus for the Pound as PM Johnson holds his first formal meeting with EC President von der Leyen.

SCANDI/EM

The overall improvement in risk sentiment has underpinned the Scandinavian Kronas and bulk of Ems, bar the Yuans pending confirmation that China’s Phase 1 deal with the US will be committed to paper this time next week.

ANALYSIS: Missile attack by Iran leaves markets pondering Trump's next move
content:
LATEST: Overnight, Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi air bases – Al-Asad and Erbil - which houses US and coalition troops. There were no reported US casualties thus far and the situation is being assessed, but sources noted casualties among the Iraqis at the Al-Asad airbase following the attacks. The rockets fired near Erbil in Iraq have reportedly hit empty fields. Iranian state TV claimed that 80 Americans were killed in the Iranian attack on US targets in Iraq, adds that US helicopters and military equipment were severely damaged in the attack; however, this has not been confirmed by the US

IRANIAN RESPONSE: Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corp claimed responsibility for the attacks and warned allied countries of the US "that if attacks are launched from bases in their countries on Iran, they will be a target of military retaliation.". Iran also threatened "more crushing attacks", including further attacks to US bases should the US respond with fresh attacks. Furthermore, Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tweets "We do not seek escalation or war, but will defend ourselves against any aggression".

US RESPONSE: The US Pentagon noted that Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles against US military and coalition forces in Iraq and will take all necessary measures to protect US personnel and allies. Thereafter, US President Trump tweeted "all is well" whilst acknowledging the missile launches, adding that "Assessment of casualties & damages taking place now. So far, so good!".

MARKET RESPONSE: In an immediate reaction to the attacks, E-mini S&P future fell from around 3225 to a low of 3181, USD/JPY fell to 107.66 from 108.35, spot gold rose from around USD 1578/oz to breach USD 1600/oz for the fist time since April 2013, printing a high just above USD 1610/oz. Brent front-month futures immediately spiked higher at the open from USD 68.50/bbl to USD 71.75/bbl. However, amid the lack of immediate retaliation from the US, a bulk of the moves above were eventually pared as markets await today’s statement from US President Trump (time TBC). For energy markets specifically, OPEC Sec Gen Barkindo was quite to downplay the impact of the attacks by noting that he expects no supply disruptions from Iraq with spare capacity running at around 3-3.5mln bpd. This followed on from comments via the UAE Energy Minster Mazrouei, that the oil market is sufficiently supplied to weather the storm.

WHAT NEXT?: The next focus for traders will be on what response the attacks will evoke from the US. US President Trump is set to issue a statement today; no time for this has been announced yet (Trump is set to receive an intelligence briefing at 1915GMT). The response by the US could prove to be indicative of whether the current situation could evolve into a full-scale conflict, however, analysts at UBS believe that Trump will offer a ‘benign’ statement. Furthermore, the Swiss Bank notes that Iran’s Foreign Minister has stated the nation had ”concluded proportionate measures” and therefore, in the absence of a firm response by the US could signal that Iran is reluctant to escalate the situation and therefore introduce some cause for optimism. This would present a more favourable case for the market and likely reflects the current retracement of some of the knee-jerk moves seen overnight. Albeit, a complete resolution to the tensions between the two nations still appears to be some way off and hard to envisage at this stage.

HOWEVER: If investors were to take a more hawkish view of the situation, it is worth considering other options the US and other actors could take. From a US perspective, America has a notable military presence in the Middle-East and Persian Gulf, with President Trump over the weekend warning that any retaliation by Iran could see the US launch attacks on 52 Iranian sites: a number which reflects the events in 1979 when 52 American diplomats and citizen were held hostage in Iran. The location of such sites is obviously an unknown (for strategic purposes), however, depending on the importance to Iran of these targets, this could trigger a full-scale conflict or cripple the Iranian economy and thereafter lead to greater global macro implications. Note, Capital Economics suggested last week that a collapse in “Iran’s economy could knock as much as 0.3%-pts off global GDP – equal to our estimate of the damage from the US-China trade war". It is also worth noting that Iran themselves still have further options and could opt to carry out further missile attacks, even on US warships and US drones, whilst also launching cyber-attacks on US infrastructure and continuing to heighten violations of the nuclear deal. Furthermore, if the situation escalates, other nations will likely be brought into the conflict with Iraq’s involvement likely to increase as well as Saudi Arabia, Lebanon, Yemen, Syria and Israel potentially set to either be a basis for Iranian attacks or help facilitate US operations in the area. Note, it is also worth noting the risk of Russia and China being dragged into proceedings, however, for the purpose of this piece, our immediate focus will be on the statement from US President Trump.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Cash markets open little changed after an eventful night; M +3.8%, STZ +3.7%, LEN +3.5%, WBA -5%, WAT -2.4%, BA -1.6%
content:
Equity futures traded in a whipsaw fashion overnight, initially tumbling after the missile attacks on US-affiliated bases in Iraq, although after it was discovered no US casualties had occurred and that further escalation was unlikely in the near term, the risk off move reversed, leading to cash markets opening Wednesday's session rather flat. President Trump is scheduled to make a speech on the matter at 11:00 EST/ 16:00 GMT.

Elsewhere, the ADP employment report beat expectations and the prior reading was revised higher by approximately double, although the market impact was muted on the release; there is little in the way of other Tier 1 data on the schedule (note Fed's Brainard [voter and neutral] speaks at 10:00 EST/ 15:00 GMT), with participants looking to the official NFP report on Friday. Meanwhile, the energy sector requires additional caution ahead of the EIA weekly inventory report at 10:30 EST/ 15:30 GMT, where private reports suggest draws in crude and Cushing stocks to be offset by builds in the products. The energy sector has opened as the underperformer amid the lower oil prices, with the defensive Utilities and Staples also lagging. Industrials trades subdued too, with gratitude to the latest fatal Boeing jet crash incident. On the other side, Financials lead on higher yields, with the risk friendly Discretionary and Communications sectors not shortly behind. 

  • M +3.8% beats expectations on holiday sales
  • STZ +3.7% & LEN +3.5% strong earnings
  • WBA -5% bad earnings
  • WAT -2.4% Needham downgrade
  • BA -1.6% fatal jet crash and Cowen downgrade

subject: European bond sales today exceeded EUR 31bln, setting an all-time daily record
Fixed and FX latest: debt remains depressed, but Buck buoyant
content: Arguably less reaction than one might expect or is warranted given the sheer size of the ADP beat and even more emphatic back month upgrade, but bonds have fallen to new intraday lows as the broad risk recovery continues. Bunds are hovering just above 171.70 for a cumulative round trip of 152 ticks from their overnight best, with Gilts down to 131.44, -1/4 point vs +14 ticks in very early Liffe trade and US Treasuries are 1 full point+ below highs. Conversely, the Dollar is consolidating or edging fresh peaks with the DXY inching closer to levels not seen since the pre-year end dump, ie DXY near 97.250 compared to 97.344 on Xmas Day.

subject: PRIMER: US ADP National Employment released at 13:15 GMT / 08:15 ET: Street expects a print of 160k, picking up from the prior pace of 67k.
analysis_details:
• Analyst expectations range from 77k to 225k.
  • Earlier in the week the employment metrics from Markit’s Non-Manufacturing survey saw the fastest rise in employment since July, and the manufacturing survey saw employment growth at the fastest since May with firms stating the increase largely stemmed from greater production requirements. ISM non-manufacturing print saw employment growth slow slightly by 0.3% but nonetheless continued to grow for 70 consecutive months and the manufacturing survey slowed by 1.5%, noting it was the fifth month of employment contraction.
  • Elsewhere, Challenger job cuts declined for the month falling from 44.6k to 33k. Employers announced plans to cut 592,556 jobs from their payrolls in 2019, 10% higher than 2018. “Confidence was high heading into the last month of the year. With some resolutions occurring in the trade war and strong consumer spending in the fourth quarter, companies appear to be taking a wait-and-see approach as we head into 2020,” Challenger said.
  • The uptick seen in jobless claims data in December (in the payroll survey week, the four-week moving average was running at a clip of 225,750 in December vs 221,250 in November) can be explained away by seasonal factors due to the later Thanksgiving Holiday in 2019; the NFIB’s ‘jobs hard to fill’ index has also risen lately, suggesting tightening labour market conditions.
  • Within the Conference Board’s gauge of consumer confidence, the differential between jobs plentiful and hard to get and jobs rose to 33.9 in December from 32.1 – while still short of October’s 35.1, it does augur well for the jobless rate on Friday's report.

subject: US Pentagon reportedly stating that Iran intentionally missed US troops at the targeted bases overnight., according to Dagres a Middle-East commentator
analysis_details:
• US Officials have confirmed no US casualties in the strikes.
  • Some desks have been highlighting that the relatively tame retaliation measures taken by Iran, with Iran themselves stating it was the least severe of their 13 options, was designed to prevent/mitigate the US from responding in such a way that significannatly escalated the Middle-East confrontation

subject: Boeing (BA) trades over 1% lower in premarket following jet crash in Iran, as well as being downgraded at Cowen
analysis_details: • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is under fresh pressure after a 737-800 jet flying to Ukraine from Tehran, Iran crashed shortly after take-off, killing all 176 passengers; current commentary suggests a technical failure was likely the cause of the accident and the Co says it is investigating it. Meanwhile, Cowen has downgraded the Co to Market Perform, where analyst Cai von Rumohr lowered his PT to USD 371 from USD 419 (BA shares last closed at USD 337.28), who is wary of potential cash flow issues due to the 737 grounding, despite his faith in the new CEO Calhoun as being a good pick.

subject: A US Official announces there were no casualties following the overnight strikes from Iran on the Iraq base
reaction_details: • In reaction to this update, Brent front month futures fell from USD 68.75/bbl to USD 68.40/bbl
analysis_details:
• As a reminder overnight, Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi air bases – Al-Asad and Erbil - which houses US and coalition troops.
  • This is Official confirmation of overnight reports that no US casualties have been reported
  • This Official confirmation may reduced the severity, or possible the likelihood, of retaliation measures by US President Trump; with analysts at UBS, prior to this confirmation, stating that they belieeive the statement from Trump will be 'benign'
  • Focus remain on today's press conference from US President Trump; note, the timing for this is currently unclear

subject: EU Commisson President Von Der Leyen notes they will never forget which side of the table they are sat on in regards to US China trade tensions, noting she believes in a transatlantic relationship but she has some issues with the White House currently
Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are softer, but not significantly so, in tentative trade ahead of US President Trumps update
  • WTI and Brent spiked overnight, with spot gold surpassing the USD 1600/oz mark
  • Iran has launched over a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi air bases – Al-Asad and Erbil - which houses US and coalition troops; no US casualties at present
  • US President Trump tweeted "all is well", he acknowledged the missiles launched by Iran at two military bases in Iraq, "Assessment of casualties & damages taking place now. So far, so good!"
  • Boeing (BA) 737-800 jet has reportedly crashed in Iran due to technical issues, reported via ISNA. From the reports, it is unclear what the technical issue is
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ADP & Consumer Credit, ECB’s de Guindos & Fed’s Brainard, supply from US, EU Commission President von der Leyen & UK PM Johnson meeting and US President Trump’s statement on Iranian attacks

GEOPOLITICS – analysis piece available on Newsquawk headline feed

Iran has launched over a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi air bases – Al-Asad and Erbil - which houses US and coalition troops. There were no reported US casualties thus far and the situation is being assessed, but sources noted of casualties among the Iraqis at the Al-Asad airbase following the attacks. CNN sources note that there have been no US casualties following the Iranian attack on Iraqi airbases but are awaiting official confirmation. The rockets fired near Erbil in Iraq have reportedly hit empty fields and there has been no attack on US consulate, according to a security official cited by NPR International Correspondent (Twitter/Newswires/CNN) US Pentagon noted that Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles against US military and coalition forces in Iraq, and it is clear that the missiles were launched from Iran - Pentagon will take all necessary measures to protect US personnel and allies. (Newswires) Iranian state TV claimed that 80 Americans were killed in the Iranian attack on US targets in Iraq, adds that US helicopters and military equipment were severely damaged in the attack; however, this has not been confirmed by the US. *N.B.1: There were also reports of a third strike at Camp Taji which was reportedly hit by around five rockets, albeit these reports were later dismissed. - *N.B. 2. There were unconfirmed reports via Al-Mayadeen that IRGC is claiming that "30 American soldiers" were wounded in missile attacks on U.S. bases in Iraq.

Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corp claimed the attacks and said it has fired "tens of missiles" at Al-Assad airbase in Iraq, via state media. (Newswires) In a statement, IRGC warned allied countries of the US "that if attacks are launched from bases in their countries on Iran, they will be a target of military retaliation.", via NYT's Fassihi. Iran also threatened "more crushing attacks", including further attacks to US bases should the US respond with fresh attacks, according to state TV cited by AFP. (Twitter) Senior official from Iranian Supreme leader's office said today's missile attacks against US targets were the "weakest" out of Iran's retaliation scenarios. IRGC Commander said Iran's attacks on US targets in Iraq was the first step and Tehran will not spare Americans, reported via State TV. (Newswires) Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tweets "We do not seek escalation or war, but will defend ourselves against any aggression" (Twitter)

US President Trump tweeted "all is well", he acknowledged the missiles launched by Iran at two military bases in Iraq, "Assessment of casualties & damages taking place now. So far, so good!" - a statement will be made tomorrow morning. (Twitter) Note: no timings for the statement were mentioned. Iranian state TV said US President Trump's tweet aims to downplay the damages caused by the Iranian attacks on US targets in Iraq. (Newswires) Earlier, US President Trump said he would like to withdraw US troops from Iraq at some point; would only consider Iraq sanctions if the US is not treated with respect. (Newswires) Meanwhile, White House spokeswoman says the WH will not release any further written statement tonight about the Iranian missile attack, via Al-Jazeera. (Twitter) 

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo says he expects no oil supply disruptions from Iraq, and currently spare oil capacity is approx 3-3.5mln BPD. UAE Energy Minster Mazrouei, that the oil market is sufficiently supplied to weather the storm; with reference to the ongoing situation in the Middle-East. (Newswires)

Reports noted that IRGC Commander Soleimani's body has been laid to rest following the Iranian strikes on Iraqi bases housing American personnel. (Twitter)

US troops at vulnerable Syrian bases are shoring up their defences and suspending operation meant to prevent IS fighters from regaining strength, according to WSJ citing US officials, adding that more forces are being deployed to the US Embassy in Baghdad. (WSJ)

Iraqi Militia Leader states that the first Iranian response happened, and it is now time for the first Iraq response; noting this will not be lesser than the response from Iran was. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia's state tanker operator has reportedly halted journeys through the Strait of Hormuz, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

Reports highlight that the KUNA News agency has been hacked, and there is no truth regarding the withdrawal of US forces., Aurora Intelligence. (Aurora) Follows on from reports that the Kuwait Defense Minister stated he has received, via the Commander of Camp Arifjan in Kuwait, an Official letter declaring the imminent withdrawal of all US forces in 3-days as according to Kuna

A Ukrainian Boeing (BA) 737-800 jet has reportedly crashed in Iran due to technical issues, reported via ISNA. From the reports, it is unclear what the technical issue is. Boeing said they are aware media reports regarding the plane crash in Iran and more information is being gathered. All passengers on board have been killed, according to Iranian state TV. Note: There has been nothing to indicate that this has anything to do with the US-Iran tensions and is purely a technical issue. Boeing has an 8% weighting in the DJIA. Subsequently, Iranian Civil Aviation Chief says they will not return the black box of the crashed Ukrainian airliner to Boeing (BA), according to local media. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded lower across the board, albeit well off lows - as sentiment took a hit after Iranian forces carried out multiple attacks on Iraqi bases housing US personnel and allies, as part of the IRGC’s operation to avenge its commander’s assassination. Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) initially plumbed the depths and underperformed amid headwinds from a geopolitically bid JPY and with the index briefly dipping below the 23k level as almost all its stocks traded in the red. ASX 200 (-0.1%) fared better as downside was cushioned by the large-cap miners and energy names benefitting from price action in the respective complexes. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp (-1.2%) conformed to the risk aversion, with losses in the mainland initially mitigated to an extent by the anticipated US-Sino Phase One trade deal signing next week. Finally, KOSPI (-1.1%) failed to glean support Samsung Electronics’ (+2.3%) prelim earnings – which flagged a smaller-than-forecast fall in quarterly operating profits, with some analysts noting it indicates that memory chip prices have bottomed out quicker than anticipated. APAC bourses climbed off lows after reports that US President Trump will not be addressing the nation – seen as a positive at the time as it indicates the US may not immediately retaliate. Furthermore, sentiment showed a slightly more pronounced turnaround after President Trump acknowledged the missile attack and noted that “all is well”.

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9450 vs. Exp. 6.9448 (Prev. 6.9690) (Newswires) PBoC skips open market operations for a net neutral daily position

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is poised to tell European Commission President von der Leyen that the UK will not extend trade deal talks beyond Dec 31st, 2020 and talks will be based on a free-trade deal and not alignment, according to a statement. (Newswires) EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier, before Christmas in a letter to UK Brexit Secretary Barclay, noted ‘issues of concern’ which include requirements for a fully independent watchdog to give EU citizens the ability to complain against the Government. (Telegraph)

EZ Consumer Confid. Final (Dec) -8.1 vs. Exp. -8.1 (Prev. -8.1)

-        Economic Sentiment (Dec) 101.5 vs. Exp. 101.4 (Prev. 101.3, Rev. 101.2)

EQUITIES

European bourses are softer this morning, as sentiment has switched from yesterday’s cautious optimism back into a firm risk-off frame of mind. Losses across indices are not too pronounced, recovering from overnight price action in futures, as we await the response from US President Trump; further analysis available in the Commodity section and the Newsquawk headline feed. In terms of sectors, this has also switched from yesterday with energy names now the only sector in positive territory; although, similarly to bourses, losses across the remaining sectors are relatively modest. As such, energy names are leading the Stoxx 600 while Co’s which are typically afflicted by higher prices are holding up relatively well roughly unchanged on the day e.g. easyJet (EZJ LN). Elsewhere, its comparatively quiet on the European stock stories front. Although, the situation is significantly different in the US where focus is on Boeing (BA), -1.9% in pre-market trade, after a 737-800 craft crashed in Iran shortly after take-off. This is reportedly due to technical issues and is not, at present, believed to be linked to the ongoing Middle-East tensions; interestingly, reports note that the Iranian Civil Aviation Chief will not be returning the black box from the craft to Boeing.

FX

USD - The Dollar’s broad recovery from post-Iran retaliatory strike lows is fairly representative of the overall retracement in currency and other financial markets amidst a relatively rapid turnaround in sentiment from aversion bordering on a scramble out of risk assets into safe-havens, albeit less pronounced. The DXY has reclaimed 97.000+ status and eclipsed yesterday’s high even though US Treasuries retain an underlying bid and the curve is marginally flatter awaiting the official US response after a full inspection of the bases hit in Iraq, and ahead of the next pre-NFP proxy for Friday in the form of ADP, assuming attention returns to fundamentals at some point.

EUR - The G10 laggard after yet another shallower rebound vs the Greenback and what looks like a fix-related run against the Pound that tripped stops in the cross through 0.8465, but stopped short of testing 0.8450 or last week’s low. The single currency now appears vulnerable to Eur/Usd sell orders said to be residing near/on Tuesday’s circa 1.1125 low that could then expose decent option expiry interest at 1.1120 and even between 1.1100-05 (in 1 bn and 1.2 bn respectively).

CHF/JPY/XAU - Very volatile trade given the aforementioned risk-off flows followed by a sharp/abrupt unwind of safe-haven premiums, as the Franc reverses from around 0.9665 back below 0.9700, Yen rotates more than a full big figure either side of 108.00 where there is a 1 bn expiry and Gold slides to circa Usd1573/oz compared to over Usd1610 at one stage.

NZD/GBP/AUD/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Buck, or holding up better amidst its revival, as the Kiwi keeps tabs on 0.6650, Aussie holds off fresh 0.6850 lows, with the aid of some welcome better news on the data front via building approvals, Sterling maintains 1.3100+ status and Loonie pares some of its losses around the 1.3000 handle. However, price action remains choppy/fluid across the board, and the Pound may be prone to more Brexit headlines in wake of UK PM Johnson’s date with new EC President von der Leyen to discuss the post-January 31 transition period and Britain’s relationship with the EU thereafter.

NOK/SEK - Some Norges Bank and Riksbank diversions for the Scandi Crowns to ponder, but not a lot new in comments from Governor Olsen or the December policy meeting minutes in truth. Hence, Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are both largely tracking wider developments and the much improved risk tone, with the former lagging as crude prices come off the boil.

EM - Most regional currencies are benefiting from the considerably calmer mood, bar those with close commodity links that are underperforming/hampered by the retreat in oil, bullion etc.

Australian Building Approvals (Nov) 11.8% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. -8.1%) (Newswires) Australian Private House Approvals (Nov) 6.1% (Prev. -7.0%, Rev. -6.0%)

FIXED INCOME

Debt futures were already in full retrench mode before the results of Germany’s auction, but the broad reversal in prices from lofty safe-haven pinnacles has gathered pace since, and for Bunds with some added technical impetus after yesterday’s Eurex low was breached. The 10 year benchmark has now been down to 171.85, and weighing on Gilts and US Treasuries in the relief that Iran’s strike back has not sparked a more aggressive return of fire from the US, for now at least. Ahead, ADP and the 10 year US offering, but the official word from President Trump will be pivotal above all else.

COMMODITIES

Another tumultuous day for markets, particularly the commodity complexes, due to the magnitude of news-flow and in the interest of time, a full briefing on recent events, including what’s next, responses so far and market reaction, is available on the Newsquawk feed. To briefly surmise the main points, overnight Iran launched missiles at two Iraqi bases (Al-Asad and Erbil), currently reports indicate that no US troops were killed but we await official confirmation of this. Markets took a firm risk-off tone, with WTI and Brent experiencing significant upside; high prints of, USD 65.65/ bbl and USD 71.75/bbl respectively. Subsequently, much of this move has pared back, with WTI now below the USD 63/bbl handle, given that comments have pointed towards a de-escalation in tensions between the US and Iran; notably, from POTUS himself. Looking ahead, focus is almost entirely on the announced press conference from US President Trump at some point today; the timing of this is currently unclear. Middle-East updates aside, we do have the weekly update from the EIA where headline crude is expected to print a draw of 3.572mln barrels which, if correct, would be a smaller draw than the 5.9mln barrels reported via API. Although, it is worth caveating that the release may draw less attention than normal given the Middle-East developments. Moving to metals, where spot gold overnight printed a fresh six-year high surpassing Monday’s just above the USD 1610/oz mark. However, similarly to crude, the yellow metals prices have drifted to reside within proximity to the USD 1580/oz figure.

Iranian VLCC super tanker STREAM has now come back online on the AIS grid for the first time since July 2019. TankerTrackers interprets this as Iran signalling its intention of keeping the Strait of Hormuz open. (Twitter)

UAE Energy Minister stated that the oil market is well supplied now and that he is not forecasting a shortage of supply unless there is a catastrophic escalation in the region. The Energy Minister added that OPEC is not discussing any steps forward right now following the tensions in the Middle East (Newswires) Note: These are the first comments from an OPEC minister following the Iranian strikes on Iraqi bases. OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ compliance last year was at 146%, according to Energyintel Bakr. (Twitter) US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (3rd Jan) -5.9mln (exp. -3.6mln, prev. -7.8mln) (Newswires)

The single currency now appears vulnerable to Eur/Usd sell orders said to be residing near/on Tuesday’s circa 1.1125 low that could then expose decent option expiry interest at 1.1120 and even between 1.1100-05 (in 1 bn and 1.2 bn respectively).

CHF/JPY/XAU - Very volatile trade given the aforementioned risk-off flows followed by a sharp/abrupt unwind of safe-haven premiums, as the Franc reverses from around 0.9665 back below 0.9700, Yen rotates more than a full big figure either side of 108.00 where there is a 1 bn expiry and Gold slides to circa Usd1573/oz compared to over Usd1610 at one stage.

NZD/GBP/AUD/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Buck, or holding up better amidst its revival, as the Kiwi keeps tabs on 0.6650, Aussie holds off fresh 0.6850 lows, with the aid of some welcome better news on the data front via building approvals, Sterling maintains 1.3100+ status and Loonie pares some of its losses around the 1.3000 handle. However, price action remains choppy/fluid across the board, and the Pound may be prone to more Brexit headlines in wake of UK PM Johnson’s date with new EC President von der Leyen to discuss the post-January 31 transition period and Britain’s relationship with the EU thereafter.

NOK/SEK - Some Norges Bank and Riksbank diversions for the Scandi Crowns to ponder, but not a lot new in comments from Governor Olsen or the December policy meeting minutes in truth. Hence, Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are both largely tracking wider developments and the much improved risk tone, with the former lagging as crude prices come off the boil.

EM - Most regional currencies are benefiting from the considerably calmer mood, bar those with close commodity links that are underperforming/hampered by the retreat in oil, bullion etc.

FIXED INCOME

Debt futures were already in full retrench mode before the results of Germany’s auction, but the broad reversal in prices from lofty safe-haven pinnacles has gathered pace since, and for Bunds with some added technical impetus after yesterday’s Eurex low was breached. The 10 year benchmark has now been down to 171.85, and weighing on Gilts and US Treasuries in the relief that Iran’s strike back has not sparked a more aggressive return of fire from the US, for now at least. Ahead, ADP and the 10 year US offering, but the official word from President Trump will be pivotal above all else.

COMMODITIES

Another tumultuous day for markets, particularly the commodity complexes, due to the magnitude of news-flow and in the interest of time, a full briefing on recent events, including what’s next, responses so far and market reaction, is available on the Newsquawk feed. To briefly surmise the main points, overnight Iran launched missiles at two Iraqi bases (Al-Asad and Erbil), currently reports indicate that no US troops were killed but we await official confirmation of this. Markets took a firm risk-off tone, with WTI and Brent experiencing significant upside; high prints of, USD 65.65/ bbl and USD 71.75/bbl respectively. Subsequently, much of this move has pared back, with WTI now below the USD 63/bbl handle, given that comments have pointed towards a de-escalation in tensions between the US and Iran; notably, from POTUS himself. Looking ahead, focus is almost entirely on the announced press conference from US President Trump at some point today; the timing of this is currently unclear. Middle-East updates aside, we do have the weekly update from the EIA where headline crude is expected to print a draw of 3.572mln barrels which, if correct, would be a smaller draw than the 5.9mln barrels reported via API. Although, it is worth caveating that the release may draw less attention than normal given the Middle-East developments. Moving to metals, where spot gold overnight printed a fresh six-year high surpassing Monday’s just above the USD 1610/oz mark. However, similarly to crude, the yellow metals prices have drifted to reside within proximity to the USD 1580/oz figure.

subject: Nomura quants say CTAs may finally be starting to sell equities and buy bonds
content:
Nomura's quant desk estimates that CTAs are likely to have begun exiting S&P 500 longs below 3,230; the next trigger line is 3,150 - if the S&P 500 can avoid slipping beneath this line, it might make its way back up towards 3,230.

  • While the overnight fall in the emini looks like an overreaction, it is clear that the Iran situation has become a destabilising factor for global equity markets. Nomura says it is difficult to tell how the US-Iran conflict might unfold from here, but notes that most speculative players spent November and December accumulating longs in US equities, to the point that their potential for further buying looks close to used up.
  • There is also a well-known tendency for specs to book profits on long positions in US equities in January, and the Iran situation could act as a tailwind towards taking profits at this time of year for short-term players, and Nomura suggets that, given the extent to which specs had until recently been moving in lockstep in accumulating equity longs, the price impact of their exits from these positions could be fairly large.
  • Nomura's model suggests that discretionary investors (including long/short funds and global macro hedge funds) have already started cutting US equity net long exposure, and the bank notes risks that the paring of their exposure could turn into a complete pullout if the Iran situation deteriorates enough to damage fundamentals (global economic growth and corporate earnings), although this is not its base case view.
  • Meanwhile, trend-following CTAs look increasingly likely to be mechanistically drawn into liquidating their long futures positions. Nomura estimates that the average break-even for CTAs’ most recent purchases (net buying of futures since the beginning of December) stands at around 3,230. S&P 500 futures have already moved beneath this level overnight, which Nomura says means that CTAs are likely to be forced into unwinding long positions.
  • "We think the next trigger line on the way down is at around 3,150, and we therefore think that in order to put a stop to selling by CTAs, the S&P 500 will need to avoid slipping below 3,150 and quickly make its way back up to around 3,230."
  • Nomura's quants also note that one of the most prominent actions by CTAs since the start of the year has been a resurgence in net buying on the major bond future markets. And while there is an argument that the stock sell-off this year has halted the rise of bond yields, and added positive momentum in the bond futures market, setting the stage for CTA's to systematically buy bond futures, Nomura argues that CTAs were already primed to swing back to buying bond futures, as their aggregate net positions in most major markets had already turned market-neutral. "Regardless, we think CTAs are still not that deep in bond future longs, and the sustainability of this trend warrants close monitoring," the bank writes.

subject: ANALYSIS: Missile attack by Iran leaves markets pondering Trump's next move
content:
LATEST: Overnight, Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi air bases – Al-Asad and Erbil - which houses US and coalition troops. There were no reported US casualties thus far and the situation is being assessed, but sources noted casualties among the Iraqis at the Al-Asad airbase following the attacks. The rockets fired near Erbil in Iraq have reportedly hit empty fields. Iranian state TV claimed that 80 Americans were killed in the Iranian attack on US targets in Iraq, adds that US helicopters and military equipment were severely damaged in the attack; however, this has not been confirmed by the US

IRANIAN RESPONSE: Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corp claimed responsibility for the attacks and warned allied countries of the US "that if attacks are launched from bases in their countries on Iran, they will be a target of military retaliation.". Iran also threatened "more crushing attacks", including further attacks to US bases should the US respond with fresh attacks. Furthermore, Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tweets "We do not seek escalation or war, but will defend ourselves against any aggression".

US RESPONSE: The US Pentagon noted that Iran launched over a dozen ballistic missiles against US military and coalition forces in Iraq and will take all necessary measures to protect US personnel and allies. Thereafter, US President Trump tweeted "all is well" whilst acknowledging the missile launches, adding that "Assessment of casualties & damages taking place now. So far, so good!".

MARKET RESPONSE: In an immediate reaction to the attacks, E-mini S&P future fell from around 3225 to a low of 3181, USD/JPY fell to 107.66 from 108.35, spot gold rose from around USD 1578/oz to breach USD 1600/oz for the fist time since April 2013, printing a high just above USD 1610/oz. Brent front-month futures immediately spiked higher at the open from USD 68.50/bbl to USD 71.75/bbl. However, amid the lack of immediate retaliation from the US, a bulk of the moves above were eventually pared as markets await today’s statement from US President Trump (time TBC). For energy markets specifically, OPEC Sec Gen Barkindo was quite to downplay the impact of the attacks by noting that he expects no supply disruptions from Iraq with spare capacity running at around 3-3.5mln bpd. This followed on from comments via the UAE Energy Minster Mazrouei, that the oil market is sufficiently supplied to weather the storm.

WHAT NEXT?: The next focus for traders will be on what response the attacks will evoke from the US. US President Trump is set to issue a statement today; no time for this has been announced yet (Trump is set to receive an intelligence briefing at 1915GMT). The response by the US could prove to be indicative of whether the current situation could evolve into a full-scale conflict, however, analysts at UBS believe that Trump will offer a ‘benign’ statement. Furthermore, the Swiss Bank notes that Iran’s Foreign Minister has stated the nation had ”concluded proportionate measures” and therefore, in the absence of a firm response by the US could signal that Iran is reluctant to escalate the situation and therefore introduce some cause for optimism. This would present a more favourable case for the market and likely reflects the current retracement of some of the knee-jerk moves seen overnight. Albeit, a complete resolution to the tensions between the two nations still appears to be some way off and hard to envisage at this stage.

HOWEVER: If investors were to take a more hawkish view of the situation, it is worth considering other options the US and other actors could take. From a US perspective, America has a notable military presence in the Middle-East and Persian Gulf, with President Trump over the weekend warning that any retaliation by Iran could see the US launch attacks on 52 Iranian sites: a number which reflects the events in 1979 when 52 American diplomats and citizen were held hostage in Iran. The location of such sites is obviously an unknown (for strategic purposes), however, depending on the importance to Iran of these targets, this could trigger a full-scale conflict or cripple the Iranian economy and thereafter lead to greater global macro implications. Note, Capital Economics suggested last week that a collapse in “Iran’s economy could knock as much as 0.3%-pts off global GDP – equal to our estimate of the damage from the US-China trade war". It is also worth noting that Iran themselves still have further options and could opt to carry out further missile attacks, even on US warships and US drones, whilst also launching cyber-attacks on US infrastructure and continuing to heighten violations of the nuclear deal. Furthermore, if the situation escalates, other nations will likely be brought into the conflict with Iraq’s involvement likely to increase as well as Saudi Arabia, Lebanon, Yemen, Syria and Israel potentially set to either be a basis for Iranian attacks or help facilitate US operations in the area. Note, it is also worth noting the risk of Russia and China being dragged into proceedings, however, for the purpose of this piece, our immediate focus will be on the statement from US President Trump.

subject: Riksbank December minutes: Since the monetary policy decision in October, economic developments both globally and in Sweden have been in line with the Riksbank’s forecasts
content:
• Given the low level of interest rates abroad, the view was that a periodically negative repo rate in the future cannot be ruled out. As always, monetary policy will be adjusted if conditions change.
  • Several members discussed the period with a negative policy rate. It was noted that this was an important reason behind the strong economic activity of recent years and the return of inflation to the target. However, it was also pointed out that more analysis is needed of the potential effects if negative interest rates are perceived as more permanent
  • Ingves: The repo-rate path is our best forecast at present, illustrating that monetary policy is in a kind of “wait-and-see” situation. The future is, as always, uncertain. Economic activity could turn out to be better and Swedish inflation could increase faster than is assumed in our forecasts. In such a scenario I am in no hurry to raise the repo rate.
  • Breman: I would prefer a repo-rate path that indicates an increase during the first half of 2020, on condition that economic activity has stabilised then, and that the repo-rate path then indicates around one rise per year in 2021 and 2022
  • Jansson: would be against increasing the repo rate at today’s meeting even if we had revised up our inflation forecast, perhaps so that it had even overshot the inflation target for a while
  • Floden: If inflation should prove to be weaker than in our forecast, it may be necessary to make monetary policy more expansionary, for instance, by cutting the repo rate back to –0.25 per cent
reaction_details: Little reaction seen in the SEK following release of these minutes
analysis_details:
• As a reminder, in December the Riksbank delivered on their well signaled 25bp hike taking rates to 0.0%
  • At the meeting Deputy Governors Breman and Jansson entered reservations against the rate hike
  • Additionally, the  Riskbank noted that in the scenario of weaker than forecast developments they could cut rates or take other measures to prompt expansionary policy

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded lower across the board, albeit well off lows - as sentiment took a hit after Iranian forces carried out multiple attacks on Iraqi bases housing US personnel and allies, as part of the IRGC’s operation to avenge its commander’s assassination. Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) initially plumbed the depths and underperformed amid headwinds from a geopolitically bid JPY and with the index briefly dipping below the 23k level as almost all its stocks traded in the red. ASX 200 (-0.3%) fared better as downside was cushioned by the large-cap miners and energy names benefitting from price action in the respective complexes. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp (-0.9%) conformed to the risk aversion, with losses in the mainland initially mitigated to an extent by the anticipated US-Sino Phase One trade deal signing next week. Finally, KOSPI (-0.8%) failed to glean support Samsung Electronics’ (+2.3%) prelim earnings – which flagged a smaller-than-forecast fall in quarterly operating profits, with some analysts noting it indicates that memory chip prices have bottomed out quicker than anticipated. APAC bourses climbed off lows after reports that US President Trump will not be addressing the nation – seen as a positive at the time as it indicates the US may not immediately retaliate. Furthermore, sentiment showed a slightly more pronounced turnaround after President Trump acknowledged the missile attack and noted that “all is well”.
